title: Jack Mytton Way Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: P L Chadwick / Waymarker on the Jack Mytton Way
images.caption: Waymarker on the Jack Mytton. Way In this rather lonely part of Shropshire, at this point the bridleway is joined by a public footpath coming in from the right which provides a connection to the Shropshire Way.

images.title: John M / Along the Jack Mytton Way
images.caption: Here the long distance bridleway passes alongside Chelmarsh Reservoir.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Riding on the Jack Mytton Way, Shirlett, Shropshire
images.caption: Riding on the Jack Mytton Way, Shirlett, Shropshire. Into the grid square by a nose!...this friendly horse riding group enjoys an early summer Sunday morning.

images.title: David Hancock / View from Jack Mytton way
images.caption: View from the trail near Much Wenlock and Shadwell Quarry

images.title: Jenni Miller / The ford at Clee St. Margarets
images.caption: The ford at Clee St. Margarets. A really pretty unspoilt village on the trail.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Grazing Land near Detton Hall, Shropshire
images.caption: Grazing Land near Detton Hall. The trail follows the wide track behind the hedge on the right.

images.title: Row17 / 'The Jack Mytton Way' along the ridge of Wenlock Edge
images.caption: The Jack Mytton Way along the ridge of Wenlock Edge

images.title: Jeremy Bolwell / Long walk on the Long Mynd
images.caption: Long walk on the Long Mynd. The Long Mynd carries the ancient Port Way and the more recent Ride UK 's Jack Mytton Way and the Shropshire Way footpath also.

description: This is a splendid walk or mountain bike ride through Shropshire from Cleobury Mortimer to Llanfair Waterdine. It passes through the wonderful Long Mynd in the Shropshire Hills AONB. Other scenic highlights include Wenlock Edge and the Clee Hills . Settlements on the route where you can pick up the trail include Cleobury Mortimer , Church Stretton , Clun and Much Wenlock . Along the way there's also great views of the Severn Valley and its accompanying heritage railway. The route is named after John Mytton (1796–1834) a Shropshire landowner, MP, horseman, foxhunter, gambler and Regency rake.
